title.value: Geographical concentration of COVID-19 cases by social determinants of health in 16 large metropolitan areas in Canada – a cross-sectional study
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the top of the provided text and encapsulates the core subject of the study, which is the geographical concentration of COVID-19 in relation to social determinants of health.
title.quote: Geographical concentration of COVID-19 cases by social determinants of health in 16 large metropolitan areas in Canada – a cross-sectional study

extractions.description: This study analyzes the geographical concentration of COVID-19 cases in 16 Canadian metropolitan areas by examining various social determinants of health such as income, education, and visible minority status. The research aims to understand the extent of concentration and its variation across different cities to potentially inform more equitable public health responses.

type.justification: The study relies on data analysis of COVID-19 cases and applies statistical methods to quantify geographical concentration, which are characteristic approaches of empirical research.
type.quote: Methods : We used surveillance data on confirmed COVID-19 cases at the level of dissemination area. Gini (co-Gini) coefficients were calculated by CMA based on the proportion of the population in ranks of diagnosed cases and each social determinant using census data...

name.justification: The primary focus of this paper is on the distribution and determinants of COVID-19 within populations, which aligns with the field of epidemiology.
name.quote: We quantified social determinants of geographic concentration of COVID-19 cases across sixteen census metropolitan areas (CMA) in four Canadian provinces.

name.justification: The study has implications for public health policy, particularly in understanding social determinants of health in the context of disease spread.
name.quote: Interpretation : The feature of geographical concentration of COVID-19 cases was consistent across CMAs, but the pattern by social determinants varied. Geographically-prioritized allocation of resources and services should be tailored to the local drivers of inequalities in transmission.

name.justification: The paper mentions using Canadian census data from 2016 as a source for information on social determinants of health.
name.quote: Data describing DA-level social determinants of health, with the exception of income, were extracted from the latest available Canadian census data (2016).

referenced_paper_title.value: Dictionary, Census of Population, 2016. Dissemination area (DA)

referenced_paper_title.quote: 17. Dictionary, Census of Population, 2016. Dissemination area (DA): Statistics Canada; 2016.

name.value: COVID-19 surveillance databases from Canadian provinces
name.justification: The study uses data from provincial COVID-19 surveillance databases to analyze case distribution.
name.quote: Individual-level data from provincial surveillance databases were used to calculate the number of SARS-CoV-2 cases per DA.

name.justification: The paper explicitly mentions the use of R for conducting data analyses, which is a common statistical computing environment.
name.quote: All analyses were conducted using R statistical software (27).
